questions.text: A patient is brought to the ER with abrupt onset of weakness of the right side of the body associated with headache and vomiting. The patient is a known hypertensive but is not adherent to medications. NCCT head is done and is shown below. Which of the following is used in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a known hypertensive patient developing weakness of the right side of the body with headache and vomiting, along with the given NCCT image showing a hyperdense collection is suggestive of hemorrhagic stroke (intracerebral hemorrhage). Out of the given options, intravenous hypertonic saline is used in the management of such cases.

Hypertensive ICH is a result of spontaneous rupture of a penetrating artery. The most common sites involved are basal ganglia (specially putamen), thalamus, cerebellum and pons. Patients present with abrupt onset of focal neurological deficit. However, the deficit worsens over next 30-90 minutes. This progression is something that differentiates ICH from ischemic stroke, because ischemic stroke is maximal at the onset itself.

Since the internal capsule lies adjacent to the basal ganglia, it is also damaged and contralateral hemiparesis is seen. Patients may also have signs of increased ICP such as headache and vomiting. The level of consciousness may progressively diminish and the patient may land up in a coma. 

The mainstay of the management of ICH is to maintain the ICP and reduce blood pressure. The target systolic blood pressure is <140 mmHg, and the preferred drug for blood pressure reduction if SBP is >160 mmHg is IV nicardipine. If there are signs of ICP elevation, osmotic therapy with intravenous mannitol or hypertonic saline is done. If the ICH has led to obstructive hydrocephalus, CSF drainage using an external drain can be done. Surgical evacuation of the hematoma has been found to the beneficial only in cerebellar hemorrhage.

There is no role of glucocorticoid administration (option B) in the management because they haven't been shown to improve outcome, and increase the risk of hyperglycemia and infections.

Thrombolysis with alteplase (option D) and mechanical thrombectomy (option C) are treatment modalities for ischemic stroke.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with pain and swelling of the left great toe since last night. Synovial fluid analysis shows leukocytes and sodium urate crystals. Which of the following drugs is not used in the acute management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with inflammation in the great toe with synovial fluid showing leucocytes and monosodium urate crystals points to a diagnosis of acute gout. Allopurinol should not be used for the treatment of acute episodes because it can worsen the symptoms.

Gout is characterized by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to the formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints. It occurs due to an increased pool of uric acid in the body due to chronic hyperuricemia. Acute episodes progress to chronic arthritis with persistent synovitis and joint erosions.

An acute episode of gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of such flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light, as shown below.

WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors (like allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (like probenecid) can be used. However, urate-lowering therapy is not started during an ongoing acute episode of gout because it can worsen the flare.

questions.text: You are asked to plan a combination therapy for a 60-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is being treated for congestive heart failure. His liver and renal functions are normal and his BMI is within normal limits. Which of the following class of drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Thiazolidinediones should be avoided in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF).

Thiazolidinediones are drugs that act by binding to the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPAR-γ), thereby reducing insulin resistance. These drugs are associated with an increase in plasma volume, weight gain, and hepatotoxicity. They commonly result in peripheral edema and are contraindicated in patients with CHF and hepatic disease. Metformin (biguanides) is also avoided in unstable CHF. 

Oral glucose-lowering agents include:

  • Biguanides: metformin
  • Insulin secretagogues: glimepiride, repaglinide
  • α-glucosidase inhibitors: acarbose
  • Dipeptidyl peptidase inhibitors: sitagliptin
  • Thiazolidinediones: rosiglitazone, pioglitazone

The management of type 2 diabetes mellitus should be initiated with medical nutrition therapy. According to the American diabetes association, vegetables, fruits, low glycemic index foods, and high fiber content is recommended. 

Other options:

Option B: α-glucosidase inhibitors reduce glucose absorption from the GI tract by inhibiting the enzyme that breaks down oligosaccharides. They should be avoided in patients with inflammatory bowel disease. The common side effects include diarrhea, flatulence, and abdominal distention. 

Option C: Dipeptidyl peptidase IV inhibitor, increases insulin levels and decreases glucagon levels. This class of drugs generally warrants a reduced dose with renal insufficiency. Serious side effects include allergy and hypersensitivity reactions like anaphylaxis, angioedema, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

Option D: Sulfonylureas act by increasing insulin secretion. These are recommended in individuals with recent onset of type 2 diabetes mellitus. These drugs are avoided in patients with hepatic and renal dysfunction. Common side effects include hypoglycemia and weight gain.

Other classes of hypoglycemic drugs:

SGLT2 inhibitors: Lead to increased loss of glucose and sodium in the urine. This leads to an increased incidence of urinary and genital mycotic infections and fall in systolic blood pressure.

GLP-1 receptor agonists: They are associated with an increased risk of acute pancreatitis and are avoided in patients with pancreatic disease.

Biguanides: They are associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is incidentally found to have high BP. Laboratory investigations show metabolic alkalosis, and reduced renin and aldosterone levels. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, metabolic alkalosis, and reduced renin and aldosterone levels, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome is the most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in the epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone.

Although the clinical presentation of Liddle syndrome is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism or Conn's syndrome (option D), it is characterized by undetectable aldosterone in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism. Note that serum renin is low in both Conn's syndrome and Liddle syndrome.

Bartter syndrome (option A) is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Gitelman syndrome (option C) occurs due to a defect in the Na+-Cl- channel in the distal convoluted tubule. Like Bartter syndrome, the patients present with hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and low to normal BP. However, these patients have hypocalciuria and reduced serum magnesium. Gitelman syndrome mimics chronic use of thiazide diuretics.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient?
  1. Atorvastatin
  2. Aspirin
  3. Clopidogrel
  4. Low molecular weight heparin
  5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
While atorvastatin, aspirin, clopidogrel, and low molecular weight heparin all have a role in the management of a patient with NSTEMI, there is no role of alteplase. 

Initial management of a patient with NSTEMI includes bed rest to decrease the load on the heart. Oxygen is administered only if the patient has hypoxemia (SpO2 <90%) or heart failure. Further management includes the following medical therapy:

Nitrates (such as nitroglycerine given sublingually) reduce the venous return to the heart, thus reducing the cardiac output and the oxygen demand. Nitrates are contraindicated if the patient has hypotension. 

β-blockers also reduce the myocardial oxygen demand predominantly by their negative chronotropic effect. Diltiazem or verapamil are given to reduce the heart rate if the patient doesn't respond to β-blockers. 

Morphine is given if the patient continues to have severe chest pain despite the administration of the abovementioned anti-ischemic drugs.

Antithrombotic therapy, which includes:

  • Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 blocker such as clopidogrel. DAPT is continued for a minimum of 3 months, but preferably for 12 months. 
  • Anticoagulants such as low molecular weight heparin and bivalirudin 

Clot formation and fibrinolysis is a dynamic process occurring in the coronary arteries. Antithrombotic therapy is given to prevent new clot formation while fibrinolysis is occurring by intrinsic or extrinsic mechanisms. 

Statins, such as atorvastatin are started because they reduce the risk of recurrence of NSTEMI and stabilize the atherosclerotic plaque in the coronary arteries.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with complaints of rectal bleeding, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. On examination, an ulcer as shown in the image is noted. Barium enema revealed a hose pipe appearance in the descending and transverse colon. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with barium enema showing a hose pipe appearance (lead pipe appearance) in the descending and transverse colon, and the image showing pyoderma gangrenosum are suggestive of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Clinically, patients present with abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea with mucus, and tenesmus. Other symptoms like anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss are also present.

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, and uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

The diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made by colonoscopy which pseudopolyps, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns called backwash ileitis.

Barium contrast enema shows a hose pipe appearance characterized by a smooth-walled and cylindrical colon with complete loss of haustrations. Fecal calprotectin and fecal lactoferrin levels will be elevated.

Severe attacks of ulcerative colitis may result in toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, and colon cancer.

Option A: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below:

 

Option C: Colon carcinoma typically arises in patients above the age group of 50 years. change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding in cases of left-sided colon tumors, and iron deficiency anemia or a mass in proximal lesions of the colon. Double-contrast barium enema shows Apple-core sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows):

 

Option D: Diverticulosis is seen in the age group of more than 50 years. The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text:
An elderly male patient is diagnosed with cardiac failure. On admission, his urine output is measured to be 200 ml/24 hours with an elevated creatinine level. Which of the following can be an indication for dialysis in this patient?

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate
questions.solution:
Uremic encephalopathy can be an indication of dialysis in this patient.

The above clinical features of oliguria (<400 ml/24 hours) and elevated creatinine levels are suggestive of acute kidney injury.

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy in which the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes and toxins. Dialysis broadly has 3 types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis in acute kidney injury (AKI) or end-stage renal disease (ESRD) can be remembered by the mnemonic AEIOU:

  • A- Metabolic acidosis that is refractory to medical treatment
  • E- Electrolyte abnormality: Refractory hyperkalemia not responding to conservative treatment
  • I- Intoxication by drugs
  • O- Severe volume overload resulting in pulmonary edema and causing respiratory distress
  • U- Uremia- encephalopathy, pericarditis, asterixis, seizures, intractable nausea, vomiting, and git bleeding.
  • Bleeding diathesis.
  • Creatinine clearance or estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 (Option B)

Other options:

Option A: Non-refractory hyperkalemia can be managed by restricting the dietary potassium intake, insulin, calcium gluconate or calcium chloride, inhalational β-agonist therapy, and potassium binding ion-exchange resin.

Option C: Volume overload can be managed with diuretics, salt, and water restriction.

questions.text: A patient presented with shortness of breath and a dry cough. His spirometry test shows a restrictive pattern. The HRCT scan is shown below. Which of the following would you expect to find in the physical examination of this patient?

choices.text: Stony dull note note on percussion

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath and dry cough, spirometry showing a restrictive defect points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. The given HRCT shows prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones, likely to be idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). The patient will have bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options :

Option A: Bronchial breath sounds are heard in patients with consolidation, such as in pneumonia. The sound from the airways is conducted to the skin better when the alveoli are consolidated. This leads to bronchial breath sounds.

Option C: Barrel-shaped chest is associated with emphysema. This occurs because of the loss of the parenchymal elastic tissue in the lung, leading to hyperinflation.

Option D: Stony dull note on percussion is seen in pleural effusion.

questions.text: Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing:
questions.solution:
Sjögren's syndrome increases the risk of developing marginal zone B-cell lymphoma (MALToma).

Sjögren's syndrome is characterized by chronic and persistent inflammation of the salivary glands. Initially, there is a polyclonal immune reaction, but additional mutations acquired over time may lead to the development of B-cells which can multiply even in the absence of growth signals. This is the point at which marginal zone lymphoma develops. Recent studies have shown that patients with Sjögren's syndrome are also at an increased risk for multiple myeloma.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein exocrine glands such as lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can occur in isolation or secondary to other systemic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, limited systemic sclerosis, and SLE. 

The patients usually present with drying of the mouth, difficulty in swallowing, and parotid gland enlargement. Ocular involvement may present as a gritty feeling beneath the eyelids. The workup includes the Schirmer test to determine the extent of tear production in the eyes, salivary flow tests, and serum investigations to detect specific antibodies, like anti-Ro and anti-La.  The presence of CD4+ cells on the labial biopsy confirms Sjögren's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A female patient came to the hospital with complaints of fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and dizziness on standing. She has generalized hyperpigmentation that is more pronounced in areas exposed to the sun. She is a known patient of hypothyroidism and is on thyroxine. Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities would most likely suggest primary adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
The electrolyte abnormality that would most likely be present in Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is hyponatremia.

Adrenal insufficiency can be divided into:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is most commonly due to autoimmune adrenalitis. These patients are likely to develop other autoimmune diseases such as vitiligo, premature ovarian failure, and autoimmune thyroid disease. Other causes of Addison's disease include destruction of the adrenal gland due to infections such as TB, hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to meningococcemia) or infiltration.

Secondary adrenal insufficiency occurs due to hypothalamic-pituitary axis dysfunction. This can include iatrogenic suppression due to chronic therapy with glucocorticoids, or because of pituitary and hypothalamic tumors. Pituitary apoplexy because of hypovolemic shock during parturition (Sheehan syndrome) can also cause secondary adrenal insufficiency.

The patients present with fatigue and loss of energy. Primary adrenal insufficiency causes hyperpigmentation due to excess ACTH, which stimulates the melanocytes to produce more pigment. Hyperpigmentation is maximally seen in areas exposed to sunlight or that which undergo friction. However, secondary adrenal insufficiency presents with skin paleness due to the complete absence of ACTH. 

The diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency is established by the ACTH stimulation test.

ACTH stimulation test (also known as the short cosyntropin test or short Synacthen test) involves the administration of an exogenous, synthetic peptide that has an activity similar to ACTH on the adrenal glands. Serum cortisol levels are measured prior to, and after the administration of the synthetic peptide. Cortisol levels lower than the cut-off value indicate a failure of the adrenal glands to increase the production of cortisol in response to synthetic ACTH — thus confirming the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Note that this will be seen in both primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Primary and secondary adrenal insufficiencies can be differentiated biochemically:

Serum ACTH: high Serum ACTH: low

Patients should also undergo screening for steroid autoantibodies and a CT scan of the adrenal glands to narrow down the cause of the adrenal insufficiency. 

Treatment is with oral hydrocortisone 15-25 mg/day in 2-3 divided doses. Long-acting agents are not preferred because they cause receptor activation even when the cortisol levels are supposed to be physiologically low in the body. Mineralocorticoid replacement is done with fludrocortisone 100-150 μg.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with progressive atrophy and weakness of his hands and forearms. On examination, he is found to have spasticity of the legs and a brisk jaw jerk.  Which of the following clinical findings would eliminate amyotrophic lateral sclerosis as a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Impaired cognitive function is not a clinical finding associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). Even in the late stages of the disease, cognitive functions are preserved — remember Stephen Hawking.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a type of progressive motor neuron disease. The pathological hallmark is the destruction and death of both upper (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN). Irrespective of what is involved first, eventually ALS will involve both UMN and LMN. The motor neuron disease involving selectively the upper motor neurons is called primary lateral sclerosis, while the one involving selectively the lower motor neurons is called spinomuscular atrophy.

Patients present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity. Involvement of the corticobulbar fibers leads to exaggerated expressions of emotion, such as excessive weeping or laughing. This is called the pseudobulbar affect. Some of the patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia.

However, the sensory, bowel, and bladder functions and cognition is preserved even in the late stages of the disease.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman with a history of migraine comes to you complaining of nausea, blurred vision, neck stiffness, and pain around 4 hours ago. You hear her describing her sudden headache as the worst she has ever had. What would be the next best course of action?

choices.text: Intramuscular injection of ketorolac and consider prochlorperazine for nausea
Arrange for an urgent lumbar puncture

questions.solution:
The complaint of a worst-ever, sudden-onset headache is generally linked to a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Thus, the next step in this patient is to obtain an urgent non-contrast CT to confirm this diagnosis.

Her symptoms like nausea, stiffness in the neck, and blurred vision can also be present in SAH. 

Thuderclap headache is a variant of migraine that can mimic the presentation of SAH. However, before diagnosing a patient to have thunderclap migraine, a proper workup to exclude an intracranial pathology is required.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of mitral stenosis is brought unconscious to the ER. Her pulse rate is 140 bpm and BP is 80/60 mmHg. An ECG is obtained and is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm with absent P waves, which is consistent with atrial fibrillation. Since the patient is hemodynamically compromised (hypotension), synchronized cardioversion is the most appropriate management.

Urgent electrical cardioversion is indicated if a patient with AF has a shock or severe hypotension, pulmonary edema, or ongoing myocardial infarction. Although there is a risk of potential thromboembolism if the patient has not been put on anticoagulation before, the need for rate control outweighs this risk. In these patients, control of the heart rate is achieved using IV β-blockers or calcium channel blockers (like verapamil or diltiazem). Additionally, they are also given subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin as soon as possible.

In hemodynamically stable patients with AF of >48 hours duration or unknown duration, there is a high risk of formation of a thrombus in the left atrium. If the patients are cardioverted at this stage, this thrombus can embolize into the systemic circulation, leading to end organ damage, such as stroke. Therefore, for these patients, any of the following two management strategies can be followed:

  • Give anticoagulation for 3 weeks → cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks
  • Start anticoagulation and do transesophageal echocardiography → if the thrombus is absent, do cardioversion (pharmacological or electrical) → continue anticoagulation for 4 more weeks. If a thrombus is present, then cardioversion is delayed by 3 weeks

Direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are preferred over warfarin for anticoagulation. However, warfarin is the preferred drug if the patient has a mechanical prosthetic valve, advanced CKD, or moderate-severe mitral stenosis.

Apart from anticoagulation, the most important aspect of the treatment of chronic AF is rate control. The drugs used for this are β blockers (such as metoprolol) and calcium channel blockers (such as diltiazem and verapamil). Reversion to sinus rhythm can be done electrically or using medications. Pharmacological cardioversion can be done using ibutilide, dofetilide and amiodarone (class III antiarryhthmics) or flecainide and propafenone (class Ic drugs).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient who presented with pleural effusion underwent diagnostic thoracocentesis. Lab investigations show the following findings. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Pleural fluid protein: 1.2 g/dL

Pleural fluid LDH: 10 units/L

Serum protein: 8 g/dL (normal: 5.5-9 g/dL)

Serum LDH: 150 units/L (normal: 80-225 units/L)
questions.solution:
Since none of the Light's criteria are satisfied in this patient, he is likely to have a transudative pleural effusion. Of the given options, heart failure causes transudative pleural effusion.

In any patient diagnosed with a pleural effusion, a diagnostic thoracocentesis, and analysis of the pleural fluid are done to determine the cause of the pleural effusion. The first step in determining the cause is to find out of the effusion is a transudate or an exudate based on Light's criteria:

  1. Pleural fluid protein / serum protein > 0.5
  2. Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6
  3. Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds the upper limit of normal for serum

If the pleural fluid meets one of these criteria, it is considered exudative pleural effusion.

questions.text: The pulse waveform of a patient is given below. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given pulse waveform shows two peaks in systole, indicating pulsus bisferiens. Of the given options, aortic regurgitation causes pulsus bisferiens.

In aortic regurgitation, the left ventricle receives extra blood due to the incompetent aortic valve, apart from the normal pulmonary venous blood coming from the left atrium. This large stroke volume when ejected with force causes the wall of the aorta to collapse due to the Venturi effect. This causes a midsystolic dip in the blood flow.

Other options:

Option B: Aortic stenosis causes pulsus parvus et tardus. The fixed obstruction of the aortic valve produces a slow rising pulse since the rate at which the blood can be ejected out of the left ventricle is restricted. 

Option C: Pericardial tamponade causes pulsus paradoxus. This is a misnomer, because pulsus paradoxus is actually an exaggerated fall in the sytolic blood pressure during inspiration, and has nothing to do with pulse. A fall of systolic BP up to 10 mmHg is seen in normal individuals during inspiration. In patients with pericardial tamponade, there is restricted filling of the left ventricle and thus the fall in systolic BP is more than 10 mmHg. 

Option D: In patients with severe left ventricle failure, alternating low and high volume pulse is seen.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with persistent productive cough and clubbing. On auscultation, wheeze and crackles are present.  The signet ring sign is seen on HRCT. Which of the following statement is false for this condition?

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis involves the upper lung fields
Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis involves central airways
Copious amount of sputum is produced

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. There is an irreversible airway dilation in this disease.

It is caused by the destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue due to complications from infections, congenital conditions, or autoimmune disorders.

There are 4 morphological types:

  1. Tubular or cylindrical type
  2. Cystic type
  3. Varicose type
  4. Traction bronchiectasis - seen in interstitial lung disease and is associated with fibrosis

Clinically, the patients present with a cough with excessive foul-smelling mucopurulent sputum. On examination, clubbing of the digits, and the presence of crackles on auscultation may be noted.

HRCT is the investigation of choice to confirm the disease. HRCT findings in bronchiectasis include:

  • The signet ring sign is seen when the dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery branch are seen in cross-section. The bronchus and artery should be the same size, whereas, in bronchiectasis, the bronchus is 1.5 times the size of the adjacent vessel.
  • Thickened secretions are seen as tree-in-bud pattern.
  • Tram track sign is seen due to lack of peripheral tapering of the bronchus. 
  • String of beads appearance is seen as alternate dilatation and constriction in varicose bronchiectasis. 
  • Cluster of grapes appearance is seen as cysts emanating from the bronchial wall in cystic bronchiectasis.

 

Treatment of bronchiectasis includes:

  • Antibiotic treatment targeting the causative pathogen (most common: H. influenzae and P. aeruginosa) should be administered for a minimum of 10–14 days.
  • Mucolytic administration: The mucolytic dornase (DNase) is recommended routinely in CF-related bronchiectasis, but not in non-CF bronchiectasis, given concerns about potential harm in the non-CF population.
  • Bronchial hygiene
  • Hydration
  • Aerosolization of bronchodilators.
  • Hyperosmolar agents (e.g., hypertonic saline).
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation
  • Refractory cases: Resection of a focal area of suppuration, lung transplantation.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated following a cerebrovascular accident. During the examination, it is seen that the patient's speech is fluent; he is able to understand what is said, but unable to repeat simple phrases. Naming of objects is also impaired. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is conduction aphasia.

Conduction aphasia is a form of aphasia in which both fluency and comprehension remain intact, but the patient shows an isolated impairment in their ability to repeat simple phrases and naming of objects. It occurs due to an injury in the dorsal perisylvian region, which connects Broca’s area with Wernicke’s area.

Other options: 

Option B: Wernicke's area lies in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It is an important area for word and sentence comprehension. Damage to this area or blockade of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery causes Wernicke's aphasia. It is a type of fluent aphasia in which comprehension is impaired to the spoken and written words or sentences. The speech is fluent, but contains jargon and neologisms. Therefore, the examiner cannot understand what the patient is speaking. 

Option C: Anomic aphasia is a very mild dysfunction of the language network. Comprehension and repetition are intact, but naming, word finding, and spelling are impaired. It is due to a lesion within the left hemisphere, including the middle and inferior temporal gyri. It can occur due to head trauma, metabolic encephalopathy, and Alzheimer’s disease.

Option D: In Broca's aphasia, the speech is non-fluent, with impaired repetition and naming. However, comprehension is preserved. Broca's area lies in the inferior frontal gyrus. Injury to this area or occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery leads to Broca's aphasia.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male came to the emergency department with complaints of fever, low backache, and swollen legs. He gives a history of passing dark brown colored urine multiple times in the past 24 hours. This began after strenuous training in the gym. The investigation results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute renal failure?
  • Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL,
  • Potassium 6.8 mEq/L
  • Creatine kinase: elevated
  • Urine dipstick: hematuria present
  • Urinalysis: no cells or casts
questions.solution:
The clinical features and laboratory findings are suggestive of acute renal failure due to rhabdomyolysis.

Rhabdomyolysis is a severe life-threatening condition, caused due to skeletal muscle damage. 

Causative factors include:

  • Traumatic crush injuries
  • Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopedic surgery
  • Compression during coma or immobilization
  • Prolonged seizure activity
  • Excessive or strenuous exercise
  • Heatstroke or malignant hyperthermia
  • Infections
  • Metabolic disorders such as hypophosphatemia or severe hypothyroidism
  • Myopathies (drug-induced, metabolic, or inflammatory).

Skeletal muscle damage causes excessive release of myoglobin, which acts as an endogenous toxin and can cause acute renal failure.

Laboratory features include elevated myoglobin, and creatine kinase. Hematuria on dipstick examination without red cells indicates the presence of myoglobin. Cellular damage in rhabdomyolysis causes increased blood levels of intracellular ions such as potassium and phosphate.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial nephritis is seen in patients who had recent exposure to medications such as PPIs, NSAIDs, and antibiotics. Laboratory features include eosinophilia, and sterile pyuria. It is often non-oligiuric.

Option B: The laboratory features in hemolytic uremic syndrome include schistocytes on the peripheral blood smear, elevated LDH, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

Option C: Acute kidney injury due to athero-embolic disease occurs in patients who had recent manipulation of the aorta or other large vessels. It may occur spontaneously or after anticoagulation therapy. Clinical features include retinal plaques, palpable purpura, livedo reticularis, GI bleeding. Investigations reveal hypocomplementemia, eosinophiluria, and variable amounts of proteinuria.

questions.text: Which of the following features are not seen in the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)?
questions.solution:
In a patient with syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), urinary sodium excretion is increased.

In SIADH, there is a failure of the body to increase the diuresis even when the water intake is more than the urinary loss. There is a slight increase in the total body water. This causes dilutional euvolemic hyponatremia (option A) and reduced plasma osmolality (option D). This causes a suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), causing a decrease in the plasma renin activity (option C).

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels are increased because of excess fluid retention. Suppressed RAAS and increased ANP and BNP together work to minimize the increase in extracellular volume and prevent edema. They also cause increased sodium excretion in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, severe sinusitis, and asthma. Labs show peripheral eosinophilia and elevated ESR. ANCA is positive. Which of the following features is false about the type of ANCA that will most likely be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Shows a nuclear type of staining

This patient with cutaneous vasculitis, peripheral neuropathy, severe sinusitis, asthma, and eosinophilia with positive ANCA is most likely to have eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss syndrome). questions.text: A patient with chronic hepatitis C presents with skin rash and joint pains for the past 10 days. He also gives a history of hematuria. Investigations show low C4 levels and positive rheumatoid factor. Which of the following will be abnormal in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms, along with chronic hepatitis C, point to a diagnosis of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. Serum cryoglobulin levels will be abnormal in this condition.

Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in colder temperatures, leading to a vasculitis syndrome called cryoglobulinemic vasculitis. This syndrome is strongly associated with hepatitis C infection and occurs due to an aberrant immune response to hepatitis C antigens.

Patients present with cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, and glomerulonephritis. Laboratory findings show circulating cryoprecipitates. Rheumatoid factor is positive in most patients, and complement levels are low.  

Other options:

Option A: ANCA antibodies are positive in granulomatous vasculitis like granulomatosis with polyangiitis(Wegener's syndrome) and Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Option C: Anti-CCP antibodies are positive in cases of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are positive in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon since the last year. Recently she has started developing skin induration in her fingers. Which of the following antibodies is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dysphagia and Raynaud's phenomenon preceding the skin fibrosis, and the limitation of skin fibrosis to the distal extremities suggest a diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. The antibody seen in this condition is anti-centromere.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is broadly divided into two subsets depending on the pattern of the skin involvement and other associated features:

  • Limited cutaneous (also known as CREST syndrome)
  • Diffuse cutaneous

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, Raynaud's phenomenon is seen earlier and is usually more severe and can lead to critical digital ischemia. The skin lesions develop much later, sometimes years after the development of Raynaud's phenomenon. The visceral organ involvement is slowly progressive and often benign. The prominent complications include pulmonary arterial hypertension, Sjogren syndrome, and primary biliary cirrhosis. Some patients with limited cutaneous SSc develop the all characteristic set of features, known as CREST syndrome:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud's phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

questions.text: You are evaluating a 17-year-old boy for Marfan's syndrome. You notice the following appearance of the chest as shown in the image below. This finding is called:
questions.solution:
The given image shows forward protrusion of the sternum and the adjacent costal cartilages. This finding is called pectus carinatum.

Pectus carinatum is also known as pigeon chest. It is seen in conditions such as Marfan’s syndrome, rickets, and childhood asthma.

Marfan's syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by a mutation in the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene on the long arm of chromosome 15. Skeletal manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include:

  • Tall stature and long limbs; upper segment to lower segment ratio is reduced.
  • Pectus carinatum 
  • Pectus excavatum or cobbler chest or funnel chest 
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Joint laxity 

The image given below shows the pectus excavatum, characterized by an increased hollowness in the lower part of the sternum.

 

The images below show two important signs seen in Marfan's syndrome: 

  • Image a shows positive wrist sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger around the wrist
  • Image b shows positive thumb sign - the thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed fist.

 

Cardiovascular manifestations of Marfan's syndrome include mitral valve prolapse progressing to mitral regurgitation, aortic root dilation leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture. Ocular manifestations include ectopia lentis, where there is upward and temporal dislocation of the lens and myopia.

Other options: 

Option B: Harrison’s sulcus refers to the indrawing of ribs resulting in horizontal grooves along the lower border of the chest due to the pulling of the diaphragm on a weak chest wall. It occurs in chronic respiratory disease in childhood, childhood asthma, and rickets.

A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination, his BMI is 41 kg/m2, blood pressure is 160/100 mm of Hg and an apnea-hypopnea index of 7. His awake arterial blood gas analysis is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

HCO3-: 25 mEq/L

PaCO2: 38 mmHg

PaO2: 98 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an obese patient with daytime sleepiness with an apnea-hypopnea index of 7 and normal ABG is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index and is calculated as number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep.

Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in a ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG). This includes measurement of breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity.

Note that waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA suggests cardiopulmonary disease or obesity hypoventilation syndrome (option B).

Narcolepsy (option C) presents with difficulty sustaining wakefulness and disturbed nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy usually feel well-rested on awakening and then feel tired throughout the day. One of the most characteristic clinical features which is seen is cataplexy – sudden muscle weakness without a loss of consciousness, which is usually triggered by strong emotions.

Central sleep apnea (CSA) (option D) is caused due to increased sensitivity to PCO2. This causes an unstable breathing pattern, which manifests as hyperventilation alternating with apnea. Prolonged circulation delay between pulmonary capillaries and carotid chemoreceptors is also a contributing cause. Hence, patients with heart failure may show CSA. They can present with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be affected in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Thoracic spine is rarely involved in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). 

In the initial stages of rheumatoid arthritis, the small joints of the hands and the feet are most frequently involved. These most frequently include the wrist, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) joints in the upper limb, and metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints in the lower limb. Cervical spine involvement can also occur, leading to compressive myelopathy. Rheumatoid arthritis rarely involves the thoracic and lumbar spine. Note that distal interphalangeal joint (DIP) involvement is not seen in RA and usually represents coexistent osteoarthritis.

The patients complain of early morning joint stiffness lasting for more than an hour, which improves with activity. As the disease progresses, the following deformities may be seen:

  • Trigger finger occurs due to tenosynovitis of the flexor tendons
  • Ulnar deviation of the hand occurs due to MCP joint subluxation
  • Swan-neck deformity occurs due to hyperextension of the PIP and flexion of the DIP
  • Boutonnière deformity occurs due to flexion of the PIP and the hyperextension of the DIP

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient presents with chronic arthritis involving multiple joints. He has a history of scaly plaques on the skin but has not taken any treatment. Findings on clinical examination and radiography are shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of scaly plaques on the skin, with the given images showing osteolysis of phalangeal bones with telescoping of the digits, indicates that it is arthritis mutilans seen in psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

Joint involvement in psoriatic arthritis can take the following forms:

  • Arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP)
  • Asymmetrical oligoarthritis
  • Axial involvement (spine and the sacroiliac joints)
  • Arthritis mutilans refers to a highly destructive form of the disease, and is the most specific finding in psoriatic arthritis

Another important feature seen in PsA is inflammation of the periarticular structures. This includes enthesitis (inflammation at the site of the insertion of ligaments and tendons), tenosynovitis, and dactylitis (diffuse swelling of the entire finger or toe, called as sausage digit). 

In patients with active arthritis, anti-TNF therapy is the first line recommended treatment. The drugs include etanercept, infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, and golimumab. If anti-TNF therapy is contraindicated or not tolerated, methotrexate, sulfasalazine or leflunomide may be effective. Monoclonal antibodies against IL-17 (secukinumab, ixekizumab) or IL-23 (guselkumab) are also being used for the treatment.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A patient presents with numbness in both lower limbs, abdominal pain, and melena. On examination, BP is 170/90 mmHg. There is gangrene of the right second and third fingers. Investigations show mild leucocytosis with increased ESR. ANCA is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of symptoms involving multiple organ systems, such as abdominal pain, melena, digital gangrene, along with hypertension, elevated ESR, and absent ANCA points to a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).

Patients typically present with hypertension (due to renal artery involvement) and abdominal pain and bloody stools (due to involvement of the GIT blood vessels). One-third of the patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B.

The microscopic examination of PAN shows segmental, transmural necrotizing inflammation. PAN primarily affects the small- and medium-sized arteries. The kidney, heart and GIT vessels are the most commonly involved ones. Lesions usually involve only part of the vessel circumference, and have a predilection for branch points. Because of these lesions, there can be impaired perfusion to the distal organs, resulting in infarcts and ischemic atrophy. 

During the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall and fibrinoid necrosis as shown in the image below. The phase of acute inflammation can also be complicated by thrombosis. Older lesions show fibrous thickening of the vessel wall extending into the adventitia. All the stages of the disease activity (acute to chronic) are often present in the same vessel.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman is brought to the ER with confusion and abdominal pain in the left lower quadrant. She was treated for a renal stone 1 year ago. She is conscious and alert, but not oriented to time or place. Her laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following is the likely underlying cause?

Serum Ca2+: 17 mg/dL (normal: 8.5 to 10.5 mg/dL)

Serum PO43-: 1.5 mg/dL (normal: 3 to 4.5 mg/dL)

Serum PTH: elevated
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with neuropsychiatric manifestations and a history of renal stone, along with elevated serum Ca2+, low serum PO43- and elevated PTH, points to a diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most likely underlying cause is parathyroid adenoma.

Primary hyperparathyroidism occurs when the parathyroid gland starts producing excess PTH. A solitary adenoma in one of the inferior parathyroid glands is the most common cause of this disorder. In rare cases, it can also be caused by diffuse parathyroid hyperplasia, or as a part of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes.

Most patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are asymptomatic. In symptomatic patients, the following clinical features are seen: 

  • Osteitis fibrosa cystica: subperiosteal reabsorption of the bone and cyst formation, most commonly seen in the phalanges
  • Neuropsychiatric manifestations such as irritability, depression, stupor, and psychosis.
  • Proximal muscle weakness and atrophy.
  • Abdominal complaints such as nausea, vomiting, and heartburn.
  • Renal manifestations such as polyuria and polydipsia (due to hypercalcemia-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus), calcium-containing renal calculi.
  • Calcium may precipitate in the cornea (band keratopathy), in extravascular tissues (calcinosis), and in small blood vessels causing skin necrosis (calciphylaxis). 

CKD (option A) will cause secondary hyperparathyroidism due to vitamin D deficiency. This will present as ↓ Ca2+, ↑ PTH, and ↑ phosphate (because it is not getting excreted in CKD).

Multiple myeloma (option B) causes increased bone resorption due to the release of osteoclast-activating factors from the tumor site. Osteoclast stimulation causes ↑ Ca2+. Phosphate is initially normal, but increases in later stages due to renal failure. PTH is suppressed because of ↑ Ca2+. 

Paget's disease of the bone (option D) does not present with any abnormality in serum Ca2+, phosphate, or PTH.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary retention. On examination, knee and ankle jerks were preserved but there was bilateral saddle anesthesia. Bulbocavernosus reflex is lost. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with flaccid paralysis of the bladder (urinary retention), along with bilateral saddle anesthesia and loss of bulbocavernosus reflex, points to a diagnosis of conus medullaris syndrome.

The conus medullaris is the term given to the tapered caudal termination of the spinal cord. It can occur due to trauma, neoplasms, herniated lumbar disc, or vascular insufficiency. Patients with conus medullaris syndrome present with bilateral saddle anesthesia, prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction, and impotence. While knee jerk is often preserved, they have a loss of bulbocavernosus and anal reflexes. Muscle strength is also relatively preserved.

Other options:

Option A: Cauda equina syndrome refers to an injury to the lumbosacral nerve roots within the spinal canal, occurring distal to the termination of spinal cord at L1-L2 level. The patients present with low back ache (most often a radicular type of pain), lower limb weakness and sensory loss, and areflexia in the lower limbs. Relative sparing of bowel and bladder functions with late-onset retention symptoms is seen. Since ankle jerk is preserved in this patient, and there is prominent bladder involvement, this option is ruled out.

Option B: Patients with Brown-Séquard syndrome present with:

  • Ipsilateral weakness due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.
  • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sense due to the involvement of the posterior column tracts.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense due to involvement of the spinothalamic tract.

Option D: Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to gray matter cells and spinothalamic tracts, which are present in the vicinity of the central canal. It occurs due to syringomyelia (cervical cord involvement), spinal trauma, and intrinsic tumors of the spinal cord. Patients with cervical cord involvement present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back, and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

questions.text: All the following are features of Wilson’s disease except___________.

choices.text: Copper in blood is of no diagnostic use
Increased urine excretion of copper is most specific screening test

questions.solution:
Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. There is a copper overload that primarily affects the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the brain (leading to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms). 

Clinical features of Wilson's disease include: 

  • Hepatic features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient might develop cirrhosis and acute decompensation of liver function. Massive release of copper into the circulation from the liver can lead to hemolytic anemia.
  • Neurologic features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia.
  • Psychiatric features include personality changes (irritability, anger) depression, and anxiety.
  • Ocular features include Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract. 
  • Other manifestations include renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis. 

Reduced serum ceruloplasmin (option A) and elevated urinary copper excretion (option D) point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Measurement of serum copper is of no diagnostic use (option C) since it may be low, normal, or elevated depending on the stage of evolution of the disease. Percutaneous liver biopsy for measuring hepatic copper content is the gold standard investigation for establishing the diagnosis.

Copper chelation in patients with Wilson's disease is done using penicillamine. Pyridoxine is prescribed with penicillamine to counteract the deficiency that may develop with the treatment. In patients with predominant neurological manifestations, trientine is used as the chelating agent because penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms. Tetrathiomolybdate is under trial for the treatment of Wilson's disease. Zinc is used for maintenance therapy in patients after the initial chelation is complete.

Mutation in ATP7A gene causes impaired copper absorption and transport, leading to Menkes disease. This is characterized by brittle and kinky hair.

An elderly man presents with fatigue and weight loss. Physical examination revealed pallor and splenomegaly. Lab reports and peripheral smear is given below. Which of the following is the most likely chromosomal translocation seen in this patient?

Hb: 10 g/dL

Total leucocyte count: 1,50,000/mm3

Platelet count: 5,00,000/mm3

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fatigue, significant weight loss, splenomegaly, a TLC of 1.5 lakh/mm3, and a low LAP score all point toward the diagnosis of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The peripheral smear showing increased white blood cells at various stages of maturation, such as myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band forms further helps to confirm the diagnosis. The chromosome translocation seen in CML is t (9;22). 

CML is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is common in males 55-65 years of age. It occurs due to the translocation between the long arms of chromosomes 9 and 22, forming the Philadelphia chromosome. This results in the activation of tyrosine kinase, which causes abnormal cellular proliferation. Common presenting features are fatigue, malaise, weight loss, and splenomegaly. 

Blood investigations show anemia, leucocytosis, and thrombocytosis. It has decreased levels of leucocyte alkaline phosphatase due to a relative increase in abnormal myeloid cells. The emergence of tyrosine kinase inhibitors as first-line therapy has dramatically improved survival for these patients. Imatinib is the most commonly used tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for CML.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with increased hand and foot size, and the facial features depicted in the image. Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-1) levels are elevated. Which of the following confirms your diagnosis?

GH - Growth Hormone

choices.text: Suppressed growth hormone after oral glucose load
Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load

questions.solution:
The clinical image of a man with mandibular enlargement, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), and jaw malocclusion with elevated IGF-1 suggests the diagnosis of acromegaly. Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load confirms the diagnosis.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

75g of oral glucose load is administered to the patient. The growth hormone levels are measured within 1-2 hours after administration. Normally, GH should be suppressed to less than 0.4 ug/L after the oral glucose load. A failure of suppression of growth hormone confirms the diagnosis of acromegaly. In some patients, growth hormone levels may demonstrate a paradoxical rise. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Elevated random growth hormone levels would not help in diagnosis as GH is secreted in a pulsatile fashion. In addition, the GH level does not correlate with severity. 

Option B - Suppressed growth hormone after an oral glucose load is seen in patients without acromegaly. 

Option D - Elevated random prolactin levels are seen in 25% of patients with acromegaly but is not used to confirm the diagnosis.

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with interstitial lung disease has chronic breathlessness. He walks slower than healthy people of the same age on level ground but does not have breathlessness on rest. How would you classify his dyspnea?
questions.solution:
This patient has a chronic pulmonary condition (ILD) and therefore the most appropriate scale for quantifying his dyspnea would be the MMRC scale. He has grade 2 dyspnea according to the MMRC scale.

The Modified Medical Research Council (MMRC) dyspnea scale is used to classify the severity of symptoms in respiratory diseases. The scale is as follows:

0 Breathless only on strenuous exercise
1 Breathless when hurrying on level or walking up a hill
2 Walks slower than peers on level ground, or has to stop to rest when walking at own pace on level ground
3 Stops to rest after walking 100 m or after walking for a few minutes on level ground
4 Too breathless to leave the house, or breathlessness present during activities of daily living

 

The New York Heart Association (NYHA) has outlined criteria that are used to classify patients with heart disease based on their functional disability. NYHA classification of dyspnea due to cardiac conditions is as follows:

  • No limitation of physical activity
  • Ordinary physical activity does not cause symptoms
II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
III
  • Marked limitation of physical activity
  • Comfortable at rest, but less than ordinary physical activity causes symptoms
IV
  • Unable to carry out any physical activity without symptoms or symptoms at rest

questions.text: A man drinks excessive water while running a marathon and develops headache, dizziness, and confusion. To correct the underlying electrolyte abnormality, large volume of hypertonic fluids were  rapidly administered to him. Following this he developed quadriparesis and pseudo bulbar palsy. What is the likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the patient has developed hyponatremia. Rapid correction of hyponatremia with large volume of hypertonic fluids lead to osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS). 

Rapid correction of hyponatremia, i.e. >8–10 mmol/24 hours or >18 mmol/48 hours, can result in ODS, which is characterized by central pontine myelinolysis. It may also cause extrapontine myelinolysis affecting the cerebellum, putamen, thalamus or lateral geniculate bodies. 

The rapid correction of hyponatremia results in water being driven out of the cell, which has adapted to a chronic state of hypotonicity, thereby leading to damage to the myelin sheath of these cells.

The clinical features of ODS include acute onset of quadriparesis, ataxia, pseudobulbar palsy and abnormal extraocular movements.

MRI is useful in establishing the diagnosis and may also identify partial forms of hyponatremia that present as confusion, dysarthria, and/or disturbances of conjugate gaze without paraplegia. MRI findings include:

  • Owl's eye appearance - due to the sparing of the peripheral pontine fibers and the descending corticospinal tracts
  • Monkey sign - due to signal alteration in the basal pons

Prevention depends on therapeutic guidelines for the restoration of severe hyponatremia. The correctin of severe hyponatremia should aim for a gradual correction, i.e. ≤8 mmol/L (8 meq/L) within 24 hours and 15 mmol/L (15 meq/L) within 48 hours.

Other options: 

Option A: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening complication that can occur anytime during antipsychotic treatment. Haloperidol is known to cause NMS. Clinical features include motor and behavioral symptoms like muscular rigidity, dystonia, akinesia, mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion. Autonomic symptoms include fever, diaphore­sis, and increased pulse and blood pressure.

Option B: Cerebral salt wasting syndrome results from hypersecretion of atrial natriuretic peptide. It is seen primarily with central nervous system disorders including brain tumors, head trauma, hydrocephalus, neurosurgery, cerebrovascular accidents, and brain death. It is associated with hyponatremia, polyuria and elevated urinary sodium excretion. Treatment is by restoring intravascular volume with sodium chloride and water.

Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is an encephalitis caused when JC polyomavirus infects the oligodendrocytes and leads to demyelination. It usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals. The patients develop focal and progressive neurological symptoms.

A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and bilirubinuria. Patients are asymptomatic and other laboratory tests are normal. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment in the lysosomes of the centrilobular hepatocytes.

Option B: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but has a milder presentation. Conjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. The liver biopsy does not show pigment deposition.

Option D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is another syndrome that has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is of two types, with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in infancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)?

choices.text: Vague abdominal discomfort is a part of the diagnostic criteria
Diagnostic criteria should be fulfilled for at least 3 months to make the diagnosis
Painless diarrhea or constipation is not a part of the diagnostic criteria
Symptoms must be present at least once a week

questions.solution:
Vague abdominal discomfort is not a part of the diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). Rome IV criteria have replaced abdominal discomfort with abdominal pain, and pain is now a prerequisite clinical feature of IBS. 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation, or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhea or constipation does not fulfill the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhea-predominant IBS. The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs). Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhea-predominant IBS and psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil has been shown to be effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with high fever, vomiting and one seizure which lasted for 2 minutes. She appears confused and is unable to answer questions properly. Her medical history is significant for Graves disease with medication non-compliance. Her family members also tell you that for the past few days she has been feeling feverish and had a cough. The cardiac monitor shows some arrhythmias. What is the most appropriate management for this patient, in addition to supportive care?
questions.solution:
This patient who has Graves disease and an acute infection, now presents with high fever, vomiting, one seizure and confusion. This is suggestive of thyroid storm or thyrotoxic crises. Management includes supportive measures and large doses of propylthiouracil (500–1000 mg loading dose and 250 mg every 4 h) given orally or via an NG tube and propranolol (60–80 mg PO every 4 h; or 2 mg IV every 4 h). 

Methimazole is used if propylthiouracil is not available. Although identificantion and treatment of the precipitaing factor is important, antibiotics and propranolol alone are not enough - anti-thyroid drugs should be given.

questions.text: On auscultating a patient, you find that splitting of S2 occurs during expiration but single S2 is heard during inspiration. Which of the following is unlikely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Splitting of S2 in expiration but not in inspiration is referred to as paradoxical or reverse splitting. It is seen in aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and left bundle branch block (LBBB). 

Normally during inspiration, there is an increased flow of blood to the lungs from the right side of the heart. This delays the closure of the pulmonary valve slightly compared to the closure of the aortic valve. Thus S2 is split into A2 (occurs early) and P2 (occurs later) physiologically during inspiration. 

Any condition that can cause delay aortic valve closure (LBBB) or obstruct the left ventricle outflow tract sufficiently to delay aortic valve closure (aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) can cause paradoxical splitting of S2. In a paradoxical split, A2 occurs after P2. During inspiration, the P2 is delayed and comes closer to A2, leading to a single S2. This is known as the paradoxical splitting of S2 because it occurs during inspiration, while the physiological splitting occurs during inspiration. 

Atrial septal defect (option D) shows a widely split S2 that does not vary with respiration. During inspiration, there is increased blood volume in the right ventricle as explained above. However, even during expiration, the blood volume remains high because blood traverses the defect from the left atrium to the right atrium. This produces the wide, fixed splitting of S2.

questions.text: The electrocardiogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows broad QRS complexes, rSR' pattern in lead V1, and a curved S wave which is wider than the R wave in lead V6. This points to a diagnosis of right bundle branch block (RBBB).

To make a diagnosis of RBBB, the following three criteria should be met:

  1. QRS duration >120 ms.
  2. rSR' pattern present in leads V1 or V2. The R' is usually wider than the initial R wave.
  3. S wave of greater duration than the R wave in leads V6.

Bundle branch blocks occur due to a block in the conduction in the right or the left bundle system below the AV node. RBBB is often seen in patients with no underlying heart disease, while left bundle branch block (LBBB) is seen associated with ischemic heart disease, cardiomyopathy and valvular heart disease.

Other options:

Option B: The ECG findings suggestive of LBBB include:

  • QRS duration >120 ms
  • Broad, notched, or slurred R wave in leads V5 or V6
  • Absent q waves in leads V5 or V6
  • QS (no preceding R wave) or rS (small R wave but deep S wave) complexes in lead V1

Option C: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome occurs due to an abnormal conduction pathway in the cardiac tissues between the atria and ventricles. ECG will show the following features:

  • A shortened PR interval 
  • A slurring and the slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave)
  • A widened QRS complex
