questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with sudden onset diminution of vision and decreased color perception in the right eye since yesterday. She also complains of intermittent weakness and pins and needle sensations in bilateral lower limbs. An MRI of the brain is done and is shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of optic neuritis (sudden onset painless diminution of vision), pins and needle sensations, and intermittent weakness, along with the given MRI showing Dawson's fingers (white-colored areas perpendicular to the ventricular surface), points to a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS).

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which there is chronic inflammation in the CNS, with demyelination and gliosis. Patients can present with a variety of symptoms:

  • Sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pins and needles sensations
  • Optic neuritis, which presents as diminished visual acuity, decreased light perception, and periorbital pain which worsens with eye movement
  • Weakness of limbs, usually of the UMN type. Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic of MS
  • Facial weakness 
  • Diplopia due to internuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction

Patients with MS report worsening of their symptoms after being exposed to heat. For instance, the symptoms may worsen after a hot shower or during a fever. This phenomenon is termed Uhtoff's symptom. It probably occurs because of the transient conduction block when the body's core temperature is elevated. Another feature seen in MS is Lhermitte's symptom. It refers to an electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back, into the legs. It is commonly induced by movements of the neck.

MRI is used for making the diagnosis of MS. The diagnosis of MS requires demonstrating that the lesions are disseminated in space (involving multiple areas of the brain) and in time (multiple episodes over a period of time). Dissemination in space is determined by evaluating the MS-typical lesions on MRI. Dissemination in time is determined by the coexistence of gadolinium-enhancing and non-enhancing lesions.

questions.text: The given test is done to check the integrity of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The test being performed in the given image is the finger-nose test, which is done to assess cerebellar function.

Coordination in the upper limb is tested by finger-nose test. The patient is asked to touch his nose with the index finger of one hand. Then he is asked to touch the examiner's index finger. He is asked to do this multiple times, while the examiner keeps moving his index finger from place to place. It is important to ensure that the patient has to stretch his upper limb to reach the examiner's finger, so that the coordination can be assessed over the full range of motion of the upper limb.

Lower limb coordination is tested by heel-shin test. The test is done with the patient lying down on a bed. They are asked to put the heel of one leg onto the shin of the other leg, just below the knee. They are then asked to run the heel down the front of the shin till the dorsum of the foot. Patients with cerebellar lesions will have a tremor when trying to place the heel on the shin, and will be unable to accurately run the heel down the entire length of the shin. Heel-shin test is shown in the images below.

 

The functioning of the posterior column tracts (option B) is assessed by Romberg's test. While performing Romberg's test, the patient is asked to stand with his feet close together, initially with his eyes open. If the patient is able to maintain their balance with the eyes open, they are asked to close their eyes. If they lose their balance and sway or fall with their eyes closed, the test is said to be positive. The examiner needs to be prepared to support the patient in case they are about to fall. 

Patients with disorders of the posterior column tracts will have impaired proprioception, and will have a positive Romberg's test. If the patient has dizziness or a tendency to fall even with the eyes open, then the lesion is likely to be in the vestibular system or cerebellum, and other relevant tests should be performed.

A patient, who is known to have familial hypercholesterolemia, is on atorvastatin and ezetimibe. However, his cholesterol levels are still unacceptably high. To reduce the risk of a major cardiovascular event, an additional monoclonal antibody, which is a PCSK9 inhibitor, is added to his regimen. They act by reducing the level of which of the following?

PCSK9 - Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9
questions.solution:
PCSK9 inhibitors act by reducing the level of LDL cholesterol.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors, the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially involving the Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age. Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >300 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Homozygotes for the disease might have total serum cholesterol even up to 1000 mg/dL. 

Treatment includes restriction of saturated and trans fats in the diet and high-intensity statin therapy. If adequate control is not achieved with statins alone, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor (Ezetimibe) or a PCSK9 inhibitor (Alirocumab, Evolocumab) can be added to the treatment.

A patient is brought to the ER with a head injury. He is found to have respiratory acidosis. Which of the following ABG report correctly represents the patient's condition?

1: pH: 7.30, PaCO2: 67 mmHg, HCO3-: 27 mEq/L

2: pH: 7.52, PaCO2: 48 mmHg, HCO3-: 34 mEq/L

3: pH: 7.30, PaCO2: 32 mmHg, HCO3-: 17 mEq/L

4: pH: 7.40, PaCO2: 37 mmHg, HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Option 1, with a pH of 7.30, PaCO2 67 mmHg, and HCO3- 27 mEq/L, correctly represents ABG findings in the case of respiratory acidosis.

Respiratory acidosis can occur as a result of several disorders:

  • Central causes include drugs such as morphine and sedatives, stroke, head trauma, and intracranial tumors
  • Diseases causing airway obstruction such as asthma
  • Parenchymal lung diseases such as pneumoconiosis and ARDS
  • Neuromuscular weakness such as myasthenia gravis, poliomyelitis, and muscular dystrophies
  • Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

An acute increase in PaCO2 can cause anxiety, confusion, and psychosis. Chronic hypercapnia results in loss of memory, daytime sleepiness, and motor disturbances such as tremors and asterixis.

Other options:

Option B: A pH of 7.52, PaCO2 48 mmHg, and HCO3- 34 mEq/L signifies metabolic alkalosis. There is increased blood arterial pH, as a result of a net gain of HCO3- or a loss of nonvolatile acid from the extracellular fluid. Compensatory alveolar hypoventilation occurs and causes an increase in PaCO2. Examples include vomiting, gastric aspiration, diuretic use, and milk-alkali syndrome.

Option C: A pH of 7.30, PaCO2 32 mmHg, and HCO3- 17 mEq/L signifies metabolic acidosis. There is decreased blood arterial pH as a result of a net loss of HCO3-. Compensatory hyperventilation will lead to CO2 washout and respiratory alkalosis. Examples include diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and toxins such as salicylates and ethylene glycol.

Option D represents a normal ABG.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of ataxic gait, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus (non-obstructive hydrocephalus) caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of:

  • Dementia (mostly executive function)
  • Ataxic or apractic gait
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too)

On imaging, dilated lateral ventricles are seen. Lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the normal to high range.

Treatment includes ventricular shunting. Gait improves more than cognition.

    Anti-La/SSB		 D. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Auto-antibodies Disease
1. Anti-histone Drug-induced lupus  
2. c-ANCA Granulomatosis with polyangiitis  
3. Anti-Scl-70 Scleroderma  
4. Anti-Ro/SSA,
    Anti-La/SSB		 Sjogren’s syndrome

Drug-induced lupus is commonly associated with antibodies to histones. It is positive for antinuclear antibody (ANA) and is rarely associated with anti-dsDNA. It can be differentiated from systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) as the symptoms appear during therapy with certain medications or biologicals. It usually resolves over several weeks after discontinuation of the offending medication. The most frequent medications implicated are procainamide, hydralazine, propylthiouracil, chlorpromazine, and lithium. 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) is associated with c-ANCA positivity. It is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (diffuse cutaneous) is strongly associated with the anti-Scl 70 antibodies. It is an autoimmune rheumatic disease with female predominance. Cutaneous features include Raynaud's phenomenon, ulcerations that heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, and loss of sweat glands. Facial features include mask-like facies and diffuse hyperpigmentation. Systemic features include dysphagia, pulmonary fibrosis, heart failure, uremia, and carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Sjogren’s syndrome is associated with anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB antibodies. It is an autoimmune disease with lymphocytic infiltration of exocrine glands and hyperactive B-lymphocytes. The disease commonly involves the lacrimal and salivary glands. This results in the characteristic presentation of sicca syndrome (decreased tears and saliva). Parotid gland enlargement is present in half of the patients.
